title: The Works of Robert Louis Stevenson - Swanston Edition, Vol. 1

snippet: Thecharacter of the neighbourhood is pretty strongly marked by a scarcityof hedges; by many stone walls of varying height; by a fair amount oftimber, some of it well grown, but apt to be of a bushy, northernprofile and poor in foliage; by here and there a little river, Esk orLeith or Almond, busily journeying in the bottom of its glen; and fromalmost every point, by a peep of the sea or the hills.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Two and a half miles from Perth, the road crosses the Almond near its junction with the Tay, and winds among plantations chiefly on the estate of the late Lord Lynedoch.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: (4-^) Cross the Almond by Cramond Bridge, and pass on the left New Saughton (Lord Aberdour), and Craigiehall (Hope Vere, Esq.) On the shore is the vilhige of Cramond, and on the right the entrance to Dalmeny Park, the seat of the Earl of Rosebery.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: On leaving Dunkeld, it runs east to Kinclaven, and after receiving a considerable augmentation to the volume of its waters by the accession of the Isla, the Shochie, and the Almond, it flows in a south-westerly course to Perth.

title: Diary of an Overland Journey from Bombay to England, and of a year's residence in Great Britain
author: Khurshed-ji, ARDSHER
snippet: This county abounds in most partswith Coal, Limestone, Freestone, and Iron ore of different species : the principal rivers ofthe county are the north and south Esk, the Almond and thewater of Leith : besides Edinburgh the metropolis of the county, and Leith,the county contains the towns and villages of Dalkeith, Musselburg, PortoBello, Lasswade, Pennycuich, Midcalder, Gilmerton, and New Haven, where

title: Diary of an Overland Journey from Bombay to England, and of a year's residence in Great Britain
author: Khurshed-ji, ARDSHER
snippet: (41.)—Edinburgh or Mid Lothian, a county of Scotland, about thirty mileslong, and in breadth from sixteen to twenty: its superficial extent is 360square miles, or 230,400 English acres; it is bounded north by the Firth ofForth, and the Almond which separates it from West Lothian or Linlithgowshire, east by the county of Haddington, south by the counties of Lanark,Peebles and Berwick, and on the west corner by part ofthe County of Linlithgow; the general aspect is pleasant; about one third consists of arableland, fertile, and highly cultivated, and affords excellent crops; the Moorfootand the Pentland Hills pass through the county, the highest point of whichrises 1700 feet above the level of the sea.
